Source: The Game Website.

121121.name: Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Online
121121.description:
User Summary

Tom Clancy’s Ghost Recon Online is a new multiplayer, third-person shooter produced by Ubisoft that will be free to play online.

121122.description:
Over a hundred years of legend awaits you and your skills as you vie to be the lucky prospector to hike out of the Superstition Mountains with The Lost Dutchman's Gold. However, this expedition for lost gold isn't for the faint of heart. You will face grizzly creatures and dastardly disasters around every corner and even the ghost of The Lost Dutchman himself while contending with your opponent's thirst for gold that grows with every nugget uncovered.

In this treacherous treasure adventure, prospectors must balance their skills to take on fierce creatures and dangerous disasters with their search of gold. Will you find the most treasure by prospecting or will the map lead you to victory? No one path guarantees victory but with the right amount of skill and a little bit of luck you can be the first prospector to uncover the famed Lost Dutchman's Gold!

Are you up to the challenge of uncovering the legendary gold of the Lost Dutchman?

The Lost Dutchman is a treasure mining game for 2-5 players in which players are competing to mine as much of the Lost Dutchman's Gold as they can before the water supply runs short bringing the hunt for treasure to a parching halt. Players can also win by successfully navigating the Community Treasure Map and finding the ever illusive Lost Dutchman's Gold Mine.
121122.name: The Lost Dutchman
boardgamepodcastepisode: Funding the Dream on Kickstarter Ep 66 Crash Games Lost Dutchman

121123.name: Aha! I Found it! Hidden Object Game
121123.description:
User Summary

Aha! I Found it! Hidden Object Game is a race against your friends and family as you compete to find 12 hidden items among a group of objects on screen. Consists of 10 stages with 277 different items to find.

121124.name: Aha! I Got It! Escape Game
121124.description:
User Summary

This is a puzzle adventure game. Solve puzzles to escape your room and move on to the next challenge. Interact with the game by shaking, twisting, pushing, and otherwise moving the Wii Remote to perform in-game actions. Enjoy alone or with family and friends.

121125.name: 3-2-1 Rattle Battle!
121125.description:
3-2-1, Rattle Battle! is a collection of twelve minigames that generally revolve around players shaking the Wii Remote in order to score points. Controlling a blue cartoon mascot named "Rattle Hero", shaking the Wii Remote causes him to perform a different action depending on the minigame. These includes firing a laser beam to dispatch enemies, bouncing up and down to weigh down a scale and growing or shrinking in size to dodge a salvo of arrows. Each minigame lasts between just three seconds to around two minutes in length.

The game features online leaderboards for high scores for two of the minigames.

Source: Wikipedia, "3-2-1, Rattle Battle!", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

121126.name: 3D Pixel Racing
121126.description:
The gameplay in 3D Pixel Racer is similar to other basic driving games. Players choose a driver, car and gameplay mode, and compete in a series of events in that mode to unlock new cars, tracks, and drivers. Every track in the game has several checkpoints at witch player's total race times are logged, so players can replay tracks to replay tracks to get the best time. The game controls on the Wii are nearly the same as those in Mario Kart Wii; the Wii Remote is held in the sideways position and used to simulate a steering wheel. The iOS version of the game uses the iPhone's built in accelerometer as a steering wheel, and two buttons on the touch-screen to control the cars' gas and brake.

Source: Wikipedia, "3D Pixel Racing", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

121127.name: Goldfield Gully
121127.description:
In the spring of 1893, a torrential season of constant downpour and flash floods exposed gold-bearing quartz in a large gully in the Goldfield Mining District in the small mining town of Goldfield, Arizona. $25,000 worth of gold began washing down the street that ran through Goldfield. The mad dash was on to collect the gold before it was gone!

In Goldfield Gully players press their luck to uncover as much gold as they possibly can before the ever-watchful eyes of the local Marshal catches them in the act. Players must choose which buildings in the town of Goldfield they will dig for gold in front of, then hide from the Marshal. Every round the Marshal visits one building, forcing the player in that building to give up his entire treasure. Players may also forgo their turn to bank their treasure by giving up half to the Marshal and "banking" the other half. The player with the most gold at the end of ten rounds wins!

121128.name: 5 Arcade Gems
121128.description:
Welcome to 5 Arcade Gems, a collection of five wacky arcade games. You can play alone or together with your friends – you will definitely find something for your taste, be it a medieval knights game or ultra-modern space shooter.

- Compete with other knights to beat the Evil Wizard's challenge in Templar Bashing.
- No hazard gets in the way of the dutiful Pizza Jungle Delivery company, not even the fierce savages who won't tip!
- Outsmart your competitors in RC Buggy Madness.
- Demonstrate your skills and reflexes in Lumberjack Trials.
- And of course, no adventure is complete without some deep space alien-bursting action in Whirling Rangers.

Source: The Publisher Website.

5 Arcade Gems is a collection of five mini-games, each of which are unlocked at the start and can be played with up to four people. Templar Bashing has players jumping over a pole and trying to not get knocked over, which players swing the Wii Remote to fly the pole in another direction, or flick the Nunchuk up to jump over it. Players have 4 lives to survive in the mini-game. In Jungle Pizza Delivery, players are delivering pizza when all of a sudden they are being attacked by Natives. In order to survive, players must run as fast they can by thrusting the Wii remote and Nunchuk up and down to survive. The players also have to get through obstacles by pressing the A button to go over them and the C button to go under them. Whirling Rangers is a shooter were players have to fly through rings while avoiding asteroids. In Lumberjack Trails, players play as a lumberjack, which players have to throw axes at the targets that are being thrown. Players will then have to go backer from the targets to make the game more challenging. In RC Buggy Madness, players have to drive their buggy to look for their batteries for their cars, and return them safely back to their base before the time runs out.

Source: Wikipedia, "5 Arcade Gems", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

121129.name: 5 Spots Party
121129.description:
5 Spots Party is the first development by CosmonautGames, which will initially be distributed exclusively through Nintendo's WiiWare service.

5 Spots Party is based on a successful "casual" game that reached number 1 in sales for 3 weeks on the RealArcade game site. This development for Nintendo has placed special emphasis on playability through the Wii Remote, and a special mode was added for this platform that enables up to 4 players to compete.

The game is based on the popular pastime of finding differences between 2 photos. There are 3 different modes and different playing options for one or more players.

Source: The Publisher Website.

121130.name: Adventure on LOST ISLAND
121130.description:
The goal of this Hidden Object Game is to
make Star Power by finding particular items
in colorful stages and defeat boss characters
that try to stop your progress! Stay focused
in order to find the most items among family
and friends in the exciting 4-Player mode.
Also each stage features a unique environment
that randomizes item positions to add more
enjoyment to the whole playing experience.
Adventure on LOST ISLAND - Hidden Object Game
offers a fantastic and fun game experience
for every type of Wii player!!

Source: The Publisher Website.

121131.name: Ant Nation
121131.description:
The beloved childhood pastime of lazy Sundays spent with a magnifying glass and an ant farm finally arrives in this challenging and addictive strategy simulation that trains your ant minions - as well as your brain. You must zap, torch, and manipulate your ants to make them tough enough to survive a variety of harsh environments and strong enough to defend the planet against evil alien robot insect invaders! It's up to you to build the best Ant Nation!

Source: The Publisher Website.

121132.name: Flush royal
121132.description:
The object of the game is to mark the most points by forming "hands" of poker.

Everyone draws 5 cards and in his turn, arises from one to five of his cards on the board, to complement the "hands" of poker, interconnected as crosswords.

At the end of the game the scoring begins.
Player scores 2 to 42 points for poker combinations:
2 points per pair to 42 points per Royal Flush.

121133.name: Taiga
121133.description:
European version, edition 4.2

From the back of the book:

NO LAWS, NO SOCIETY, NO HOPE
You are not protected by any laws. Killing you is not a crime.
Calling the police is of no use, even if the phones were working.
Their job is to protect the real people from the likes of you.
You do not exist in official records.
Authorities could not care less if you starve to death.
If you are sighted where the ordinary people live, you'll be shot.
Of every 100 people in the world, 94 share your fate.

The doom of Humanity lies not in the atomic weapons or wars of ideas. It comes cloaked in hunger, disease and pollution. It comes when the Earth is too poisoned to sustain us all.

The rich and powerful have walled themselves off the world and live in their computer-controlled gardens, while outside the electric fences there are no laws, society or hope. Only immense mazes of decaying towns and hastily built beggar huts.
Beyond them lies the wilderness, where small communities here and there clench their teeth to defend themselves from the bandit hordes that rule the roads and bartertowns of the world. Mutants are hiding in the desolate reaches of the world and in the cities organized crime is trying to establish a society of its own.
Small kingdoms are founded on heaps of trash, only to be toppled by barbarian hordes on wheels.

This is the world of Taiga
Where people, plagued with mutations and new diseases, roam the dying world, searching for the peace and the future that is no longer there.

2039 will be the happiest new year yet!

User comment on the Foreward to this version

(Foreward by Ville Vuorela)
Vuorela states that European version 4.2 differs from earlier versions of Taiga by having been given more thorough proofreading, being printed on high-quality paper, having a different layout and including more illustrations.

However, one of the most obvious changes for players of earlier versions is the removal of cybertech from the game. In Vuorela's words "Taiga is not a cyberpunk game. Earlier versions did include rules for using and implanting cybernetics into characters, but they have been removed from this version because they attracted too much attention and disrupted the lotek-atmosphere of the game."

From page 159 of this version, the following future products were listed (in the following order) but as they don't appear on the Burger Games website, they have most likely gone unpublished: -
VTV102 Taiga: Supplement
VTV102 Roadgang Encyclopedia
VTV110 Taiga: Radical
VTV120 Taiga: Big Blue
VTV130 Taiga: Raider!
VTV103 Legacy Of The Golden Horde

121134.name: El Emperador de Jade
121134.description:
The Jade Emperor

In the Jade Emperor players to take the Chinese zodiac signs to play.

The purpose of to travel the game board with zodiac signs in order to become the first to bring the final square your chips on the board.

The game board boxes contain divert to other players boxes and if you find another sign of the zodiac enemy in the same square, occupying the box the player must start again from scratch.

The first player to wear their zodiac three chips tabs at the end of the course wins the game.


El Emperador de Jade es un juego de estrategia sobre un tablero que refleja un año lunar chino y sus correspondientes estaciones anuales.
He diseñado un sistema de movimiento que no depende de ningún dado para ello, y si los jugadores lo desean tampoco serán necesarios los dados para los eventos, pudiendo utilizar ciertas cartas como sustitutos, pero si además quieren jugar una partida más rápida en tiempo, pueden usar un sistema mixto que acelera la mecánica del mismo reduciendo el tiempo a la mitad.
El tablero es algo más grande que el de un ajedrez 12×10 y aunque pueda parecer que en un principio es un juego de recorrido, este juego tiene un alto grado de estrategia y planificación, de forma que los jugadores deberán tener en cuenta como juegan con sus fichas y los posibles movimientos que más les interese realizar.
Los eventos son muy simples pero con un alto grado de implicación en el juego y como interactúen con ellos puede suponer una ventaja tanto como una desventaja a la hora de mover sus fichas, pero que nadie crea que se puede quedar esperando a que llegue una mejor oportunidad, por que otros signos del zodiaco podrán capturarles y dar al traste con los planes del más oportunista.
Para el control de azar los jugadores pueden disponer de dados o de cartas y los recursos que deben obtener los jugadores son limitados, pero el sistema también atiende a los casos que se pudieran producir vacíos de elementos y los puede volver a retornar al juego, aunque ciertas fichas de los jugadores pueden ser retiradas del tablero de juego no es un juego por eliminación y desde el primero hasta el ultimo dispondrán de las mismas oportunidades.
Otro tema que me parece interesante destacar es el turno en el que jugaran los diferentes participantes, en este aspecto no es un juego lineal y excepto en la primera ronda, los jugadores moverán sus fichas por el orden descendente a la posición en el tablero, de esta forma los jugadores se alternan pudiendo mover diferentes veces en cada ronda de juego según tengan posicionadas sus fichas, de esta forma si hay muchos jugadores nadie se aburrirá esperando a que le toque su turno.
Por ultimo otro tema que me parece se debe destacar es el de los componentes, todo el juego completo incluido el tablero son tres hojas de A4, y en realidad con el tablero y la Rueda zodiacal el juego tendría la base mínima de componentes, con unas fichas de colores del parchís, un dado de ocho, y uno de seis podrías jugar sin tener que imprimir nada más.
No obstante he incluido el juego al completo, el juego básico son tres hojas, y una hoja más para las cartas, para quien desee imprimirlas, las realice en formato pequeño para imprimir en papel adhesivo y pegarlas en cartas de pequeño formato, baratas y fáciles de conseguir en “todo a 100″, todas las cartas entran en un A4.
Espero que disfrutéis jugando tanto como yo diseñándolo.
A imprimir y jugar un saludo.

121135.name: Geo le Jeu
121135.description:
You need to get photos of the world to accomplish a story by answering questions.

Early in the game each player chooses a mission. Each mission is complete once player has recovered 5 photos matching the mission: 5 pictures of animals (one for each continent).

Each player moves his pawn on a game board representing the world by throwing two dice.

Next the box where it happens, he wins, loses or steals a photoby answering a question. If the answer just that question, you win the number of shots on the box (between one and three).

To win the game player must get 5 pictures related to his mission and finish her world tour.

121136.name: Gauntlet III: The Final Quest
121136.description:
From Wikipedia: Gauntlet III: The Final Quest is a home computer game by U.S. Gold and Tengen it was released in 1991. Besides the standard four main Gauntlet characters: Thor, Thyra, Merlin, and Questor, four new playable characters were available: Petras, a rock man; Dracolis, a lizard man; Blizzard, an ice man; and Neptune a Merman. The game is viewed from an isometric perspective and includes a two-player cooperative multiplayer mode.

It is an original game with a isometric projection type view that would later be used in Gauntlet Legends and other Gauntlet games made after Legends. Its view is much like that of Solstice. The player walks around various areas of each kingdom, passing from one area to the next, forest areas and castle dungeons, with logs, tables and other obstacles blocking the player's path, creating a maze-like area. Each area has at least one doorway or pathway to the next. At times certain things must be done in order to advance into the next area.

Other elements from the series also make an appearance, such as potions that make enemies disappear or weaken them, food (both good and poisonous), invincibility amulets, and treasure chests, some of which can contain traps or other items the player would need.

Source: Wikipedia, "Gauntlet III: The Final Quest," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

121137.description: A mini expansion for the "The Three Musketeers: The Queen's Pendants" board game. Consists of a sheet of rules and 2 black plastic guard figures. These "elite" guards are added to the Cardinal players reserve and are like the regular guards except for the fact that they have a higher chance of hitting and are removed from play if eliminated.
121137.name: The Three Musketeers: The Queen's Pendants – Elite Guards expansion

121138.name: Rogue Bounty Beta
121138.description:
From the Introduction:
This documents is a preliminary rules set for Rogue Bounty, a “role playing” game. The game takes a group of players through a story in which a group of antisocial, headstrong individuals stake everything in the pursuit of wealth and freedom.

121140.name: 1001 BC A Mediterranean Odyssey
121140.description:
User Summary

1001 BC A Mediterranean Odyssey is a graphical adventure game based on Homer's Odyssey. The player leads Ulysses and his companions on their journey to Ithaca after the war with Troy.

The game is a mix of exploration (the player trying to plot a course to Ithaca) and text adventure. The player controls Ulysses and can give orders to companions, but their loyalty decline over time and they may refuse to carry out orders, or even go on their way.

121141.name: The Rocky Horror Show
videogameversion: English/European Amstrad CPC Floppy Disk edition
121141.description:
User Summary

An action adventure game inspired by The Rocky Horror Picture Show. Your significant other has been petrified by Dr Frank, and he has split the de-medusa machine (which you need to invert the petrification) into several parts scattered all over his mansion. You must explore the house and recover the machine parts, while avoiding the strange denizens of the house.

121142.name: Shebang
121142.description:
From the RPG description here on RPGGeek:
Subtitled: 'Tis Not Another Space Opera

Shebang is a sci-fi RPG set approximately 1,000 years in future. The world is a different place. In fact, for all intents and purposes, the world is gone. Humans have settled on Mars and the fourth rock from the Sun is the new home world. The old civilization of "science and idealism" collapsed centuries ago. In its place is an iron clad technocracy. The utopian dreams of the free-thinkers were warped by corruption and finally crushed by those who just didn't give a damn.

121143.name: Alive
121143.description:
User Summary

You, James Butterfly, have been chosen to be the test pilot for the F49, the latest NASA prototype, a fighter capable of escaping the earth's athmosphere. The test flight is going fine, until you blacked out and the F49 vanish from the NASA radar screen.

When you wake up, you're lying in the snow, next to your crashed experimental plane and the body of your co-pilot. Picking up the few salvageable items you find (a first aid kit, a sidearm, a portable cassette player), you set out to explore the icy wilderness surrounding the crash site. Soon you encounter a group of people wearing primitive clothing and weapons. They take you to their leaders who hand you a tape. The tape is an audio recording of a prophecy foretelling your arrival on this strange world...

Alive is an icon-driven adventure game, with light RPG elements (the character's health must be monitored as it's possible to die from hunger or dehydration).

121144.name: Chimp & Zee: Pesky Pirates
121144.description: Pirate-themed children's game in which 2-4 players move around an island collecting gold to place inside their treasure chest. The game utilizes a spinner which will either indicate the number of spaces to move, or will cause another player to lose gold. When all the gold is collected, the game ends with the player having the most gold in their treasure chest being declared the winner.

121145.name: Sistema Daemon V1.01
121145.description:
From the introduction:
Crie seu próprio Universo!
Utilizando as regras genéricas do Sistema Daemon, você
será capaz de desenvolver seu próprio mundo de RPG, seja ele
fantasia medieval, ficção futurística, adaptações de seriados, filmes
e quadrinhos, suplementos, complementos, guias de equipamentos
e manuais de monstros, criaturas, deuses e entidades.
Para o Mestre, uma grande vantagem, já que toda a parte
de regras já está pronta: resta a ele apenas a parte CRIATIVA do
processo de desenvolvimento do universo de jogo... bolar intrigas,
aventuras e situações, criar NPCs, magias e rituais, desenvolver
raças fantásticas, monstros e deuses, projetar vilas, cidades,
regiões, países e até mesmo mundos inteiros.
O Sistema Daemon também apresenta grandes vantagens
para o Jogador, que possui agora um sistema simples, prático e
barato para ensinar novos adeptos as maravilhas do RPG!

User Translation from Portuguese (by way of Google Translate):
Create your own universe!
Using the general rules of Sistema Daemon, you will
be able to develop their own world for role-playing, be it
medieval fantasy, futuristic fiction, adaptations of TV shows, movies and comic books, supplements, guides, equipment,
and manuals of monsters, creatures, gods and entities.
For the GM, this is great advantage, as the rules are ready for you: it remains to you only create the game universe ... come up with plots,
adventures and situations to create NPCs, spells and rituals, develop fantastic races, monsters and gods, designing towns, cities, regions, countries and even entire worlds.
The system also has major advantages for the player, who now has a simple, practical and cheaper to teach newcomers the wonders of role-plaing !

121146.description:
The goals of this expansion are to flesh out some of the abstracted technologies within the original Origins (e.g. Obsidian, Iron, Roads) and to avoid the problems of a cycle of “nothing to do” turns that can happen in some games. The other consequence of this expansion is that geography plays a much larger role after Era I and well into Era IV (which seems to be keeping with the intended theme given Phil’s Jared Diamond references). England is well placed to become a powerhouse in Era III and China can no longer be ignored. With a good foothold, the New World has great growth potential. Finally, before this expansion, in many games, Era II only lasted 2-3 turns despite representing over 30 ky and this expansion hopes to make Era II more interesting.

Important: This expansion assumes use of the Age of Reason Expansion (Era IV) and does not use the Animal Farm Expansion (playing from American Megafauna) but can likely be easily adapted and can use the alternate brain maps or be played after Bios Megafauna.

Features:
- 25 Map Hex Overlays: Featured on the overlays are new resources to be
exploited (including Coal, Jade and Trade Crops), a new south Pacific Route to
the New World and the Toba Event.
- 10 New Innovation and Population Actions: Including Interbreeding, Emissaries
and Publication.
- 9 Infrastructure Track Overlays: With new Infrastructure bonuses including
Clipper Ships, Organic Farming and Paved Roads.
- 2 Full Color Player Guides: Includes all the new Actions, along with a Terrain
Guide, Selected Glossary and Slavery Rules. The Color makes it much easier to
read (at least for me).
- A Detailed Manual: Includes Wikipedia based footnotes in the style of the
original manual.
- Rules for porting the game over to High Frontier
121146.name: Origins: “Fleshed Out” PnP Expansion

121147.name: Hyperspace 4
121147.description:
User Summary

Hyperspace 4 is a French graphical text adventure game. Your time machine prototype works well, too well in fact, and you end up stranded in Egypt, in 1721 BC with your machine is out of fuel. Will you be able to find enough uranium to power your machine and come back to your own time?

121148.name: Attentat
121148.description:
User Summary

3:30PM, your phone rings: there's a bomb hidden in the ambassy and it will go off in 45 minutes. Evacuating the building takes 25 minutes, and you're left with 20 minutes to find and disarm the bomb.

Attentat is a graphical text adventure, played in real time (the player has 20 minutes to find the bomb, or the game is lost). The text parser is written to accept complete sentences instead of just verb+name.

121149.name: Citizens
121149.description:
designer summary

Citizens is a Macintosh application for Traveller (Classic) that generates characters with one of several backgrounds: navy, marines, army, scouts, merchant, other, pirate, belter, sailor, diplomat, doctor, flyer, barbarian, bureaucrat, rogue, noble, scientist, hunter, or assassin.

It follows the rules in Book 1: Characters and Combat, Supplement 04: Citizens of the Imperium and Scouts & Assassins (Second Edition).

At each point in the character generation rules where the player may select options, these are offered, along with a description that includes the success die roll and die modifiers, if any.

121150.name: High Guard
121150.description:
designer summary

High Guard is a Macintosh application for Traveller (Classic) that generates characters with a Navy background.

It follows the rules in Book 5: High Guard (Second Edition).

At each point in the character generation rules where the player may select options, these are offered, along with a description that includes the success die roll and die modifiers, if any.

121151.name: Mercenary
121151.description:
designer summary

Mercenary is a Macintosh application for Traveller (Classic) that generates characters with an Army or Marines background. It follows the rules in Book 4: Mercenary. It includes two starting options for the player character:


Enrollment in the Military or Naval Academy as defined in Military Academy: An Option for Mercenary. Application to flight school for marine characters achieving honors is not supported. A +1 DM on promotion die rolls is available for both army and marine academy graduates.



Enrollment in college as defined in Book 5: High Guard (Second Edition). Application to medical school or flight school for characters achieving honors is not supported.


At each point in the character generation rules where the player may select options, these are offered, along with a description that includes the success die roll and die modifiers, if any.

121152.name: Merchant Prince
121152.description:
designer summary

Merchant Prince is a Macintosh application for Traveller (Classic) that generates characters with a Merchant Service background.

It follows the rules in Book 7: Merchant Prince.

At each point in the character generation rules where the player may select options, these are offered, along with a description that includes the success die roll and die modifiers, if any.

121153.name: Scouts
121153.description:
designer summary

Scouts is a Macintosh application for Traveller (Classic) that generates characters with a Scouts background.

It follows the rules in Book 6: Scouts.

At each point in the character generation rules where the player may select options, these are offered, along with a description that includes the success die roll and die modifiers, if any.

121154.name: Seabase Delta
121154.description:
User Summary

Seabase Delta is graphical text adventure. You're the famous reporter Ed Lines and you've been captured by enemy agents and sent to the mysterious seabase Delta. You must discover its secrets and find a way to escape.

The game was written by Peter Torrance and Colin Liddle using the Quill game engine.

121155.name: Jump Jet
121155.description:
Back of Box

Rising from a small grove close to enemy lines, you hover above the trees, poised for battle. In a few short moments, you'll be tearing through perilous battle theaters in fierce low-level combat. Combat that will have you baffling opponents with sudden mid-air stops. Performing breathtaking maneuvers. And providing close-air support to your troops along the front lines.

It's the beginning of a whole new level of excitement aboard the Harrier Jump Jet...one of the world's top combat tested warplanes and the most unique flight simulator you'll ever pilot.

Through dazzling, state-of-the-art graphics, you'll experience fast-paced gameplay in multiple close-air support sorties. And you'll take full control of unusual flight capabilities like ski jump take-offs, hovering, and flying in reverse.

The Harrier Jump Jet. Once you experience it, you'll never settle for conventional jet fighting again.


Fly three different Harrier models: AV8B; GR7; plus a special Microprose Harrier.



Stunning graphics create seamless landscapes with "real" rivers, valleys, and shorelines.



Forward looking infrared goggles for clandestine night missions.



New targets and missions generated as you fly.



Varying difficulty levels for each battle theater, and each Harrier model.

121156.name: Battle of Britain (1985)
videogameversion: English/European Amstrad CPC Floppy Disk edition
videogamehonor: 1985 Golden Joystick Best Strategy Game of the Year Nominee
121156.description:
User Summary

A computer game simulating the summer of 1940 Battle of Britain, published in PSS's Wargame Series.

The player controls RAF fighter squadrons, assigning missions, patrol routes and objectives to defend. The player must also monitor squadron fuel levels, air bases state of repair, and radar coverage. Battles are resolved either automatically by the computer or by playing (optional) arcade sequences (aerial dogfight, or shooting down german planes with a flak battery).

The game includes three modes: training (one day of fighting against a weak enemy), blitzkrieg (also one day, against a tougher opponent), and campaign (30 days of fighting).

121157.name: Chaos of Three Kingdoms
121157.description:
User Summary

Chaos of Three Kingdoms is a strategy game. This game can be played online and it is set in ancient China. You need to lead your country in many fights against enemy countries and cities, to do so you have at your disposal different strategies and battle formations

121158.name: Darkness Rush: Saving Princess
121158.description:
User Summary

Darkness Rush is a fantasy game, you take the role of a vampire who has to fight against a werewolf and a Dark Dragon to recover your true love Freya.

121159.name: Shades of Heroes Beta v 1.5
121159.description:
User Summary:

a free, new version of the fantasy role-playing game Shades of Heroes, originally published back in 1998.

121160.name: So What's That Shiny Thing, Anyway?
rpgissuearticle: Review: So What's That Shiny Thing Like, Anyway?
121160.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Deep in the dungeon, the PCs have finally bested the foul ogre after an epic struggle and with glee loot their fallen enemy’s chambers. With excitement in their eyes, they ask “So what treasure did the ogre have, anyway?” An answer such as “300 gp in gems, three pieces of jewellery worth 200 gp each and a large rug” is somewhat of an anticlimax, but who has the time to prepared detailed treasure descriptions these days?

So What’s That Shiny Thing, Anyway? banishes these problems by providing 28 pre-generated, ready-to-use lists containing hundreds of detailed items for the busy GM to immediately use in his campaign.

This product is a Dual Format PDF. The downloadable ZIP file contains two versions, one optimised for printing and use on a normal computer and one optimised for use on a mobile device such as an iPad.

121161.name: Random Hill Encounters
121161.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Got barely enough time to prepare the module? Want to include cool, evocative random encounters in your games, but just don’t have the time to prepare them? Bored of pointless random encounters comprising bands of generic monsters that only seem to exist to attack wandering PCs? Then Random Hill Encounters is for you!

Presenting eight ready-to-use random encounters ranging in EL from 1—12 (and 20 stat blocks ranging from CR 1/2—10) all suitable for use in any range of hills, Random Hill Encounters takes the pressure off the time-crunched GM, enabling him to concentrate on crafting cool, evocative adventures!

Encounters include:


Barrow of the Sleeping King (EL 5): A forgotten barrow has recently been opened, but of the thieves there is no sign. What lies within?
Multi-Legged (EL 8): A basilisk and a centipede-infested shambling mound have struck up an unlikely alliance and prey on travellers passing their lair.
Mercenaries (EL 4): A small detachment of mercenaries (and their hobgoblin leader) are returning to their camp after failing to secure a contract for their services.
Savage Rage (EL var.): Savage orcs lurk within the hills. These stat blocks and suggested encounter groupings provide the backbone of dozens of encounters against with savage marauders.
Sentinels of Thor-Dilak (EL 2): The survivors of a dwarven patrol pick their way through the hills carrying the bodies of their fallen comrades home.
Sounds and Fury (EL 12): An usual pair of ogre and hill giant lurk in the hills ready to demand a toll of those passing through their territory. One controls powerful magics, while the other is an unsubtle, but ferocious warrior.
What Goes Around (EL 1): The merchant Ulwen is in need a help. His caravan was recently attacked by orcs. Almost all his guards lie dead, his horses have fled and one of his wagons is broken.
Wyverns? (EL 9): Mutant spawn of the feared red dragon Burnfyre soar through the sky in search of food. Woe betide those they come across.


This product is a Dual Format PDF. The downloadable ZIP file contains two versions, one optimised for printing and use on a normal computer and one optimised for use on a mobile device such as an iPad.

This ZIP file also contains a separate PDF containing the product's compiled stat blocks enabling the busy GM to build up a handy library of ready-to-go stat blocks.

121162.name: So What's The Human Called, Anyway? II
121162.description:
Publisher's blurb:

So your PCs have wandered into a nearby town. Perhaps they are relaxing in the tavern talking with the locals, haggling with a merchant or trying to gather information about a nearby ruin from a sage. Then they ask “so what’s this bloke called, anyway?” At this point, the GM normally uses the first name that pops into his head (probably “Bob,” or the one he used minutes ago for another NPC) crushing the players’ suspension of disbelief.

So What’s The Human Called, Anyway? II banishes this problems by providing 500 first names and 250 surnames and place names of Carolingian, Egyptian, Germanic, Gothic and Sumerian origin. Divided by culture, these handy tables enables the busy GM to generate literally thousands of unique names for use in his campaign. Players can also use the tables herein to create cool names for their PCs that suit the background and flavour of their GM’s campaign.

Featured Cultures:


Carolingian
Egyptian
Germanic
Gothic
Sumerian


This product is a Dual Format PDF. The downloadable ZIP file contains two versions, one optimised for printing and use on a normal computer and one optimised for use on a mobile device such as an iPad.

121163.name: The Secrets of Tactical Archetypes II
rpgissuearticle: Of Knives and Plagues: More Archetypes for The Secrets of Tactical Archetypes II
Review: The Secrets of Tactical Archetypes II
121163.description:
Publisher's blurb:

A fair fight is a sign of poor tactics

The Secrets of Tactical Archetypes II offers fourteen new options for conflict-oriented characters who want to do more than just fight with honor they want to lead their companions to victory! These are new options that compliment the original but this book functions on its own as a stand-alone product.

Create a Force Commander (Wizard) and manipulate you foes as if they were on a chess board! Play an Aethurgist (Oracle) and bind the spirits of the dead to your will! Design a Circle Warden (Witch) and bond your group together in a ring of abjuration.

Within these pages you will find:


Alchemist: Spellchymist a gifted resercher whose extracts take effect at range, emulating the spells of others.
Barbarian: Savage Tactician, pedagogue barbarians versed in the art of guerrilla warfare.
Bard: Umbral Weaver, a master at manipulating and listening to the forgotten secrets of shadows.
Cleric: Pious Sentinel, able to change the tide of battle by praying for their allies, and inspiring them with bursts of divine strategical insight.
Druid: Elementalurgist, focuses on the very building blocks that allow for nature’s grandeur to aid his allies
Fighter: Peltast, specialized skirmishers and masters in the art of hurling weapons swiftly and quickly.
Inquisitor: Grand Inquisitor who focuses on his spellcasting and overwhelming presence to impart judgment and strike divine fear upon the unworthy.
Monk: War Scholar, Born-strategist, a war scholar’s wisdo allows him to manage his troops with an efficiency that can reverse the most uneven odds.
Oracle: Aethurgist, renowned for her ability to bind spirits to do her bidding.
Paladin: Purifier, militant healers who providing warmth, comfort, and health to the innocent.
Rogue: Vicious Opportunist who always seems to strike at his enemies at the best moment for maximum effect.
Sorcerer: Magilith, whose bloodline power is altered due to being born at a convergent point, or node of eldritch might.
Witch: Circle Warden, unities fellow creatures inside a ring of abjuration.
Wizard: Force Commander, who sees, and shapes, the world as a giant battlemap or chess board whose sole limits are the range onto which they can control a foe.


Each archetype offers a distinct and complete theme, shifting your character's emphasis towards the wise command of allies operating as a unit. Show the enemy that good leadership doesn't discriminate; master The Secrets of Tactical Archetypes II today.

121164.name: Khufusiris, the Crooked Sleuth of Unfathered Sin
rpgissuearticle: Review: Faces of the Tarnished Souk: Khufusiris, the Crooked Sleuth of Unfathered Sin
121164.description:
Publisher's blurb:

"Be careful who you trust here, friends. Not everyone is as trustworthy as me."

In a realm where reality bends and half-truths walk in darkened alleys, trust is hard to come by. From those uncertain clouds comes lovable Khufusiris, with his dopey grin and easy jokes, providing advice and insight for any young traveler looking for a friendly face - or hoping to retrieve what has been stolen. But this mongrel creature is more than he appears, and far less friendly than he seems, and when backs are turned he knows best how to twist the cold knife of betrayal.

This product provides Game Masters with details on a shaggy sphinx found amongst the Faces of the Tarnished Souk, ready for immediate use in any campaign - but especially for use within the Coliseum Morpheuon. Each entry features ingenious stat blocks from multiple OGL sources, history, motivation, secrets, and insight into the NPC's most carefully guarded dreams, along with complete game statistics for low, middle, and high levels of play.

Within you will find:


Khufusiris, a bestial betrayer and thief-taker with a hardboiled heart.
CR 17 advanced betrayer primordial riven magic criosphinx
CR 13 advanced primordial riven magic criosphinx
CR 9 advanced primordial criosphinx
Betrayer, Primordial, and Riven Magic creature templates, for an ancient anti-magical antagonist with advanced avarice
A new magical tattoo for hungry hunters
Feats for draining defenses, playing possum, and ignoring armor

121165.name: Hellfire Magic
121165.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Hellfire – the stuff of legends and nightmares. Classically associated with the wrath of the gods and the acrid scent of brimstone, hellfire is also one of the background elements of hell and the torments that await there. Hellfire represents a common element of many fantasy stories and classic mythologies, but has very little presence within the Pathfinder Roleplaying Game. The Genius Guide to Hellfire Magic adds hellfire as a new option for a broad range of spellcasters, adding options for grim antipaladins wielding hellfire scourges, determined inquisitors calling down hellfire cages to imprison their enemies, and even good-aligned clerics and wizards drawing on the building blocks of hell to fight for justice and honor – though facing constant temptation to call upon more vile forces as they do so.

So, what is hellfire? For purposes of this product, hellfire is both a supernatural form of energy (which is similar to, but not exactly the same as, the mystic fires mortal spellcasters call upon to fuel such spells as burning hands and fireball), and a planar material (similar to magic force effects, such as those used to create everything from a simple shield to a forcecage, though not as resilient as force effects). Entire planes of existence are composed largely of hellfire, where it serves as both unescapable prison and endless and unforgiving torment to the spirits and outsiders consigned to those planes. Like the magic forces it is similar to, hellfire can be conjured, evoked, and bound into tools and defenses by mortals using powerful spells.

Hellfire is an important part of Hell and the Abyss, and as a result of being exposed to its supernatural heat, most demons and devils are either immune to normal fire or extremely resistant to it. Many evil outsiders have been so infused with hellfire that they can call upon less cosmic flames as natural abilities, and their constant manipulations and exposure have infected hellfire itself with a link to the raw powers of evil.

121166.name: What's in my Pocket?
121166.description:
Publisher's blurb:

It’s fairly common for randomly generated treasure to include a few mundane or low-value items. While these may be appreciated and hoarded for the few coins they can raise at low-levels, fairly early in most campaigns players stop caring much about items taken from the standard equipment tables (players only appreciate so many sunrods). However, sometimes a GM wants to spark some interest and mystery without handing out a major magic item, or at least make a world seem more in-depth by providing some colorful items that suggest they have a backstory behind them. To assist in such efforts, this product provides 110 odd little items, none of which will be of great use to players, but all of which might pique their interest.

To be on the list, an item had to be small enough to fit in a pocket, belt pouch, or backpack. Its weight had to be negligible, and its value low. None of these items give bonuses to rolls or checks. Rather, the items were designed to encourage players to ask questions and to act as starting points for GMs who wanted to introduce some new story hooks. These are creative motes and ideas rather than specific story elements, and they are best used by GMs who like creating stories and rumors on the fly. Even if one of these items didn’t encourage further investigation when found, it may provide another great opportunity for a GM to create a colorful background when characters attempt to sell it.

Unless an item gives a specific value, these items are worthless (or if the GM prefers worth 1 cp) or valued at 10 gp. While in most cases it should be obvious whether an item is a minor valuable or essentially junk, ultimately it’s left as an exercise for the GM to decide which is which – while mithral shards may be valuable in one campaign and a rat jawbone worthless, it would not be difficult to conceive of an economy that reverses those valuations.

121167.name: Automatons
121167.description:
Publisher's blurb:

In 2011, Dreamscarred Press held a contest for a Psionic Bestiary. The monsters from that contest are being released in a series of releases and will ultimately be compiled into a single psionic bestiary book.

In this release of the Psionic Bestiary are three monsters, the Automatons, creatures from beyond the known worlds who seek to destroy the phrenic scourge and all creatures associated with them. Relentless constructs immune to psionics, they are dedicated hunters and killers of the tentacled beasts who seek to usurp and control the other races.

121168.name: Psychic Warrior Powers
121168.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Do you hate having to carry your book or jump back and forth in a PDF to look up a psionic power? Do you want all the powers your character knows at your fingertips? Then these Psionic Power Cards are just for you!

This set of power cards contains all the Psychic Warrior powers from Psionics Unleashed. The powers are arranged alphabetically and by level.

Each card contains the rules and description of a single psionic power. If you play a psychic warrior, then this product is a must-have.

121169.name: Psion/Wilder Powers
121169.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Do you hate having to carry your book or jump back and forth in a PDF to look up a psionic power? Do you want all the powers your character knows at your fingertips? Then these Psionic Power Cards are just for you!

This set of power cards contains all the Psion/Wilder powers from Psionics Unleashed. The powers are arranged alphabetically and by level.

NOTE: The powers of the different psion subclasses (Telepath, Egoist, etc) are not included in this set.

Each card contains the rules and description of a single psionic power. If you play a psychic warrior, then this product is a must-have.

121170.name: Magic Items as Characters
121170.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Magic Items as Characters is a short supplement for Dungeons & Dragons 4th edition that gives all the necessary tools to players and Dungeons Masters who want to create sentient magical items for their games. It uses the same feats, classes, powers, and level system already familiar to D&D players to quickly create new and dynamic characters.

Magic Items as Characters seeks to maintain the balance of D&D 4th edition while injecting entirely new ideas into the system. These Magic Items can become an interesting player character, joining the party in their adventures. They can also become important NPCs, weapons of great power coveted by many power figures while they themselves work towards their own goals. Consider that powerful Magic Items are important parts of mythology and modern story telling, from the Hammer of Thor to the Elder Wand of Harry Potter. Why should your D&D games be denied this level of mystery and excitement?

121171.name: A Giant's Guide to Adventuring
121171.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This latest book by Drowning Dwarf Games gives players and Dungeon Masters the power to add Giants to their adventures. Inside, readers will find rules for playing large sized characters, information about giant society, details for five different giant races, beautiful original artwork, and more. Pick this book up today and experiance a whole new way of playing Dungeons and Dragons!

121172.name: d66 Pirate Bases
121172.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Ever needed a name right now and all you could think of was "Bob"? Do you want quick descriptions and details fill out your adventures? The d66 series is the answer for you. Each list consists of 36 possibilities to get you out of a pinch. Set in the Foreven Sector, each list comes ready to be integrated into your OTU game. Just roll your d66 and you have your answer.

Even pirates need a place to rest, refuel and sell their ill-gotten goods. In d66 Pirate Bases, you get all the names for those locations that your characters can either visit, makes black market deals or bombard from orbit (it is the only way to be sure).

15 Draeva Mining Outpost
32 Garaad City
63 Tortuga Station

121173.name: d66 Pirate Ship Names 2
121173.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Ever needed a name right now and all you could think of was "Bob"? Do you want quick descriptions and details fill out your adventures? The d66 series is the answer for you. Each list consists of 36 possibilities to get you out of a pinch. Set in the Foreven Sector, each list comes ready to be integrated into your OTU game. Just roll your d66 and you have your answer.

d66 Pirate Ship Names 2 gives you even more names for ships that attempt to take over the character's ships. These ships are ideal for everything from raiders ships to smugglers, gambling vessels, and flying drug labs. Never be short of a name again with these d66 names.

25 Darrian Rifter
43 Lehmenn Sacks
54 Raging Lion

121174.name: Inspector Gadget: Advance Mission
videogameversion: North American Game Boy Advance edition
121174.description:
User Summary

Inspector Gadget: Advance Mission is Game Boy Advanced game clearly based off the Inspector Gadget cartoons. You play as the Inspector in this 2D platform style game. During the game you will travel to New York, China, Egypt and more in your quest to stop Doctor Claw.

121175.name: Dwarven Cities
121175.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Beneath the mountains of the frozen north, in magnificent, sprawling cities carved out of the living rock, dwell the insular frost dwarves. Their realms and culture are a mystery to other races, for dwarves do not welcome guests into their homes. But that is about to change.

This supplement looks at the dwarf race in more detail, giving players new background material on which to draw, and GMs more information to help make a visit to a dwarven city something to remember.

121176.name: Kid's Cards
videogameversion: North American Game Boy Advance edition
121176.description:
User Summary

Kid's Cards is small compilation of five kid friendly card games. The games included are:

-Crazy 8's
-Old Maid
-Go Fish
-War
-Slap Jack

121177.name: The Sunken Realm
121177.description:
Publisher's blurb:

The Sunken Realm was once a populous land, though one whose inhabitants remain shrouded in mystery. Today, it is a god-cursed realm of sundered earth and shattered cities, a devastated wasteland populated only by ferocious orcs and giants, and insane frostreavers and Vendahl. Few have cause to walk the vast basin, and most who enter never return.

121178.name: Hrimthyr Isle
121178.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Since the time of the Blizzard War Hrimthyr Isle has been a bastion of evil, home to thousands of Thrym’s barbarous servants. Although the frost giants suffered a bitter defeat a century ago, their strength is building once more. Huge longships packed with giants and orcs once again plague the eastern coast, while within the walls of the mighty fortress of Jarlshof, High Ice King Nagal plans an invasion.

This supplement looks at the powers of High Ice King Nagal and the perils that await explorers to the forbidding isle of eternal winter, present four new locales, inroduces seven new prc tribes, and details four new wintry hazards.

121179.name: Richelieu's Guide to Fencing Schools 2
121179.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Two swordsmen lock blades with their rivals atop the roof of a moving carriage. One, a muscular man, swings a large sword at his opponent’s legs, hoping to trip him and send him tumbling into the roof. The other casually flicks her blouse open another button, distracting her wide-eyed opponent long enough to deftly thrust her rapier between his ribs. Unorthodox tactics, but all is fair in war! This supplement provides details on new fencing schools and their special Talents, and is a companion volume to Richelieu’s Guide to Fencing Schools, requiring use of that supplement.

Inside you'll find notes on simulating swashbuckling movie combat, background on and unique Talents for ten new major fencing academies, four minor academies, new rules for firearms and feinting, two new Talents, and ways of modifying your sword.

121180.name: Richelieu's Guide to Healthcare
121180.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Musketeers are men and women of action, battling France’s many enemies, and with combat comes the risk of injury. Whether sword cut, pike thrust, musket shot hole, broken bone, or jagged slashes caused by some hellish beast, sooner or later the characters are going to need to see a doctor.

This supplement contains a brief history of medicine, a recent timeline of medical advance, notes on various medical professions, sample disease, advice on how to create medical characters, new Flaws, five sample characters, and a page of lackeys willing to help cure your every ill.

121181.name: Richelieu's Guide to Finances
121181.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Money may be the root of all evil, but it is an essential part of life for aristocrats and peasants alike. This supplement takes a look at financial matters in the early 17th century. As a game supplement, it is not intended to be an accurate historical discourse.

Inside you'll find an overview of France's financial status, notes on taxation, exchange rates into livre for many common currencies, advice on using money in the game, campaign advice for rich characters, four sample characters, and eight new lackeys.

121182.name: Richelieu's Guide to Alchemy
121182.description:
Publisher's blurb:

The science of the ancients, alchemy represents mankind's first foray into understanding the nature of his world through experimentation and observation. While it introduces the concepts of scientific methodology, alchemy is a pseudoscience, blended with astrology, religion, and mythology.

This supplement delves deeper into the forbidden art of alchemy, providing both background notes intended to add more flavor to the game, and new game mechanics expanding the magickal tradition. Four alchemist characters and a bunch of lackeys likely to be found in their employ round out the supplement.

121183.name: BIAT
121183.description:
User Summary

A graphical adventure in game in which the goal, as an agent of the BIAT (Bureau International Anti-Terroriste) is to infiltrate and destroy a terrorist organization. The game is icon-driven and has light RPG elements (the main character is defined by 5 stats chosen by the player).

121184.name: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (GBA)
videogameversion: North American Game Boy Advance edition
121184.description:
The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring is a 2002 cross-platform video game developed based on the first volume of J. R. R. Tolkien's The Lord of the Rings. WXP developed the game for Xbox, while Surreal developed the PC and PlayStation 2 version, and Pocket Studios delevoped the game for Game Boy Advance. All three versions of the game are published by Black Label Games, an imprint of Vivendi Universal Interactive. Unlike the subsequent games published by Electronic Arts, The Fellowship of the Ring game was not designed as a tie-in to Peter Jackson's The Lord of the Rings film trilogy that was being released around the same time. The game received mixed to average reviews, earning a score of 59/100 based on 19 reviews at Metacritic, whilst IGN gave it 7.5/10

A Game Boy Advance version was released in September 2002 to North American audiences, and to Europe two months later. It greatly differed from its counterparts on other consoles, most notably for its RPG-style turn based battle system. However, the game was poorly received by critics. Most of the complaints came from the extremely slow gameplay, as well as the first few characters being comparatively weak, this is made up for later on when the rest of the Fellowship become available, but doesn't last, as Frodo is the only available character in the final mission of the game. It was also notorious for its poor quality; the game contained many glitches which greatly hindered the player's progress and sometimes even forced them to restart the entire game.

Source: Wikipedia, "The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (video game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

121185.name: Tales of Darkness
121185.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Dare you venture into Darkness?

The Dark Night - Buried in secret, Helfrith Helasdohtor a powerful priestess has been slowly breaking the sigils of her ancient tomb. When the sigils fail, the great evil will once again be unleashed onto the unsuspecting world. In preparation for this second coming of darkness, Hela has stirred Helfrith from her dreamless sleep. Can our heroes stop this evil?

The Demon of Duncallaich - The demon Kithreth lies trapped and bound to the soil of an ancient lost town Balyeux, which was destroyed during the Demongate Wars. Its taken many years for Kithreth to loosen his bonds but now he is slowly returning to the world and a cult is aiding his release. Can he succeed in his escape or will he be defeated - only you can find that answer!

Tales of Darkness contains two fantastic adventures for Triple Ace Games’ epic fantasy setting, Hellfrost.

121186.name: 480 BC: The Spartans
121186.description:
User Summary

"Work your way up to 300 Spartans you must fight with great Strategy for the Glory and Honor of the Spartans and their ForeFathers!"

121187.name: Spiritual Warfare the RPG
121187.description:
From the RPG Description here on RPGGeek:
Spiritual Warfare the RPG is a Christian table-top roleplaying game.

A land filled with unfathomable mystery, fantastical words of power, religious and political clashes of epic proportions, and a spiritual conflict as old as time itself. A setting full of valiant men, stout dwarves, nimble elves, and kindly halflings.

Welcome to the world of Spiritual Warfare the RPG. Now you can join the fight against The Devil and his forces of darkness. Unsheathe your sword, mount your steed, put your trust in the Lord, and tear down the demonic forces that have ravaged the earth. The day of evil is here; will you be able to stand?

Included in the Spiritual Warfare the RPG Handbook: Skill based character creation allowing for originality and diversity in the characters. A simple yet realistic game system that is both fast and flowing. Discipleship roleplaying that encourages Scripture memory and preaching the Gospel. Four Character Orders and many Callings to choose from.

121188.name: Spiritual Warfare: the RPG (4th Edition)
121188.description:
User Summary: Fourth Edition of Spiritual Warfare: the RPG.

From the RPG description here on RPGGeek:
Spiritual Warfare the RPG is a Christian table-top roleplaying game.

A land filled with unfathomable mystery, fantastical words of power, religious and political clashes of epic proportions, and a spiritual conflict as old as time itself. A setting full of valiant men, stout dwarves, nimble elves, and kindly halflings.

Welcome to the world of Spiritual Warfare the RPG. Now you can join the fight against The Devil and his forces of darkness. Unsheathe your sword, mount your steed, put your trust in the Lord, and tear down the demonic forces that have ravaged the earth. The day of evil is here; will you be able to stand?

Included in the Spiritual Warfare the RPG Handbook: Skill based character creation allowing for originality and diversity in the characters. A simple yet realistic game system that is both fast and flowing. Discipleship roleplaying that encourages Scripture memory and preaching the Gospel. Four Character Orders and many Callings to choose from.

121189.name: Foes Manual Volume 1
121189.description: User Summary: "Monster Manual" equivalent for Spiritual Warfare: the RPG

121190.name: Hexagone
121190.description:
Object of the game is to be the first players to have toured the multicultural France (central hexagon) and have successfully responded to the ultimate question.

Each player rolls the dice to determine his home community (Africa, Asia, No Paper, North Africa, France, Europe)

In his turn, a player rolls the dice and moves his pawn as many spaces. If it lands on a space issue, it must draw a card question and answer it before the end of the hourglass, otherwise it returns to its original square. If it lands on a space event, he must draw an event card and follow the instructions.

After answering a final question of his community, the game is won.

rpgitemversion: lulu EPUB for Adobe Digital Editions Version
121191.name: The Village of Fair Havens
121191.description: User Summary: an adventure/sourcebook for Spiritual Warfare: the RPG, describing the village of Fair Havens and it's surroundings, and the opportunities for adventure therein.

121192.name: Anchorhold
121192.description:
From the publisher's website:

Anchorhold is a complete campaign setting for a fantasy game. It includes a description of the border valleys beneath the castle of the Anchorite Brotherhood, adventure seeds full of politics and bloodshed, random encounters, event tables and name lists.

121193.description:
In Grandpa Beck's Cover Your A$$ets, a.k.a. Big Deal, players compete to collect items to become a millionaire. The game consists of 110 cards, with each card being either an asset (e.g., home, yacht, stamp collection) worth $5-20,000 or silver (worth $25k) or gold (worth $50k); silver and gold are jokers and can represent any other asset. Each player starts with 4-5 cards in hand, and on a turn a player takes one of four actions:


Play a pair of asset cards (or an asset and a joker) from hand, placing it mostly on top of any other cards acquired earlier.
Play a card from your hand that matches the top card of the discard pile, then place this pair on your other assets.
Attempt to steal the top assets from another player's collection.
Discard one card from your hand.


When trying to steal, point to the top assets you want to take, then place a matching card (or a joker) from your hand onto the table. The player who owns these assets can then do the same thing. Players go back and forth this way, and the last player to play such a card keeps all of the cards played and the original assets.

At the end of each turn, players refill their hands to 4-5 cards as needed. Once the draw pile runs out and one player has no cards left in hand, the round ends. All players tally the value of all cards in their collection and add this sum to their total score. If a player now has at least $1 million, she wins; otherwise, players shuffle the cards and start a new round.
121193.name: Grandpa Beck's Cover Your A$$ets

121194.name: Wandern -- oh, wandern
121194.description:
Objective: be the first to reach the target (field 70)
- moving by turn -
‘Roll and Move’ game
move according die roll; ending on a marked space follow instructions glued on cover inside
Equipment: board, 6 meeples (can be extended up to 8), 1 die

121195.name: Grandpa  Beck's Golf
121195.description:
GOLF®
THE LOW SCORE WINS
Players each begin with nine cards face down and then use the following simple steps to try and get the lowest score to win.
This game is inspired by the classic face card game called golf.
Now the game is fully developed game with custom cards, rules, and numbers of cards per suit to make the original concept much more engaging.

Uniquely fun for youth and adults! Easy to learn, but there is interesting strategy to make it interesting for everyone.

here are the basics of play:

1. Draw One Card from Either the Draw Pile or The Discard Pile.
2. Place the Card Drawn Face up In Your Grid to Replace One Card in Your Grid.)
3. The Card Replaced Goes in the Discard Pile.
4. Three Identical Cards in a Row or Column Are Removed for a -5 Point Bonus.
5. First Player to Expose All Cards Earns -5 Bonus Points – If They Have the Lowest Score that Round – If not a +10 Penalty is Imposed.

121196.name: Justice League: Injustice for All
videogameversion: North American Game Boy Advance edition
121196.description:
Justice League: Injustice for All is a video game that was released in 2002 by Midway Games for the Nintendo Game Boy Advance and it was based largely on the Justice League animated television series, including its character portrayals, and artistic style. It features many levels and alternate characters can be playable.

Source: Wikipedia, "Justice League: Injustice for All", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

121197.name: Justice League: Chronicles
videogameversion: North American Game Boy Advance edition
121197.description:
Justice League: Chronicles is a video game based on the Cartoon Network animated show and it was released on November 12, 2003. This game has 3 levels and each has two characters. On the first stage is Green Lantern and Flash, on the second is Batman and Hawkgirl; And the last are Superman and Wonder Woman.

Levels
1· Dark Winter: The Flash and Green Lantern have to stop Killer Frost, but on the last part they discover that she has allied with Eclipso.
2· Trial in Ape City: Gorilla Grodd acquires Amazo and uses him to frame the entire Justice League for crimes against Gorilla City. Batman and Hawkgirl break free so that they can clear their names.
3· Savage Time: Very similar to the series' episode of the same name. Vandal Savage changes history in order to help the Nazis win World War II. Superman, Wonder Woman and Martian Manhunter go back in time to stop him.

Source: Wikipedia, "Justice League: Chronicles", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

121198.name: Kill Switch
videogameversion: North American Game Boy Advance edition
121198.description:
Kill.Switch is a third-person shooter video game developed by Namco in 2003 for PlayStation 2, Xbox and Microsoft Windows. A Game Boy Advance adaptation was released in 2004. The GBA game was created independently of Namco, due to a licensing deal with Destination Software.
As a relatively straightforward third-person shooter, the most distinguishing characteristic of Kill Switch is its cover system, a mechanic that has the player character taking cover behind objects and around corners in a manner similar to Namco's own Time Crisis series of light gun shooters as well as Koei's third-person shooter WinBack and Konami's stealth game Metal Gear Solid 2: Sons of Liberty. However, Kill Switch was the first third-person shooter to feature the cover system as its core game mechanic, and introduced the blind fire mechanic to the cover system.
Story

The game is a remotely controlled super-soldier, Nick Bishop. For most of the game the soldier is remotely controlled by a man known only as "Controller." Controller is apparently using a direct neural connection to Bishop. Bishop's suppressed memories occasionally break through, causing Controller headaches. The memories feature a woman and the phrase, "Say my name." Controller, under orders from a man named Archer, uses Bishop in a series of combat missions designed to convince two nations or groups known as the North and the West to go to war. Archer plans on war profiteering in the resulting war, in part by selling copies of the technology that controls Bishop. Moments before Bishop launches a warhead equipped with a biological agent, a woman known as "Duchess" takes over Bishop, in the process causing a surge that kills Controller. Duchess uses Bishop to attack the base Controller is operating from and eventually restore Bishop's memories. It is revealed that the woman from Bishop's memories was his new wife. She was killed by Archer when Archer captured Bishop. Archer wanted the technology in Bishop for resale. Freed, Bishop makes a final assault on Archer. Afterwards, Archer is killed and Bishop walks away.

Source: Wikipedia, "Kill Switch", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

121199.name: We Are Here To See The Evil Wizard Kormákur
rpg: We Are Here To See the Evil Wizard Kormákur
121199.description:
From the publisher's website:

A group of brave souls have traveled through dark forest and hissing swamp to reach the moss-covered tower that now stands before them. They are each here to see the dreaded wizard Kormákur, but apparently Kormákur is not home.

We Are Here To See The Evil Wizard Kormákur is an experimental game about a group of people who have converged on the remote tower home of the evil wizard Kormákur, each with a grievance and none of whom is exactly what they seem.

121200.name: Blueberry
121200.description:
User Summary

A computer adaptation of an adventure of Lieutenant Blueberry, a graphic novel by French artist Jean Giraud (aka Moebius). Blueberry and his companion Jim McClure are searching for an abandoned gold mine, rumored to be near the Dead Horse Mesa.

The game mixes graphical adventure (with digitized images from the graphic novels) and arcade sequences.

121201.name: Black Grimoire
121201.description:
publisher blurb

The BLACK GRIMOIRE is a collection of spells of a Magikal or Priestly nature, including Illusory, Runic, Rogue, Demon, Dragon, and Druidic magiks, along with all Alchemical and Herbal recipes and concoctions, published by Grimoire Games and taken from the Arduin Grimoires (Volumes 1 through 8), The Arduin Adventure, The Complete Arduin, and several previously unpublished sources.

121203.name: Computer Scrabble Deluxe
121203.description:
User Summary

A computer adaptation of the boardgame Scrabble. The game can be played against either human or computer opponents, or a mix of the two. The difficulty level of the computer opponents can be chosen. The game also allows the display colours to be changed.

121204.name: Legendary Lands of Arduin: World Book of Khaas
121204.description:
publisher blurb

The World Book of Khaas, Legendary Lands of Arduin is an exciting, 800+ page volume: a literal encyclopedia of the world of Khaas and the country of Arduin. The World of Khaas, Legendary Lands of Arduin is a massive volume based on David Hargrave's work, once and for all throwing wide the gates on the Plateau of Forever; allowing entry not only to Arduin, but into the very world.

Gone are the days of wondering what lays beyond her borders.Departed are the times when your have dreamed of roving her dusty trails or foraging in the dangerous woods of the world.Its landscape is open, unraveled for the eye to behold. Khaora, the wondrous continent that houses Arduin, is mapped, its geography open to your eye. Joining it are not only the rest of the civilizations on the continent but also glimpses into the other six continents as well.

The World of Khaas, Legendary Lands of Arduin has 821 pages and over 80 professionally rendered campaign maps, showing the World of Khaas, the Continent of Khaora and the Country of Arduin in a level of detail never before seen in any published campaign setting.

This comprehensive guide to the world was inspired by Dave Hargrave. It was written without mechanics or game system material and is compatible with d20 or other fantasy role playing game system.

This soft cover version of the World of Khaas features the original full color cover and while trimmed to a shorter 821 pages than its predecessor the black hardcover version it actually has even more content than that original publishing! This new printing includes 10 more pages interspersed throughout the book and over 700 changes to spelling, grammar, organization and layout. How did we do this? We consolidated charts, condensed the index and reorganized the material to slim down the manuscript while taking away nothing. Everything from the original production is in this amazing volume. With the new method of publishing you get to enjoy the original full color cover as well as additional material!

121205.name: Conspiration: Le Défi des Derniers Rois
121205.description:
User Summary

A graphical adventure where the protagonist receives a mysterious phone call one day of 1989, and soon ends up in the late 18th century, forced to take part in several plots for or against the young French republic.

The game uses a text parser (which only accept commands given in the imperative tense, and not using the infinitive as was usually the case in French Amstrad CPC adventure games) and digitized images.

The game was released less than a year before the 1989 celebrations commemorating the French Revolution.

121206.name: Erebus
121206.description:
User Summary

You are a spy sent to Antarctica to investigate a plot to destroy all the wildlife there. While flying a reconnaissance mission under the guise of a volcano study expedition, your plane engine fails and you find yourself crashlanding in the middle of the snow. You have no gear, the temperature is below zero, a flight of unidentified birds hovers menacingly above your head. What do you do?

Erebus is an icon-based adventure game, with survival elements (the character must find ways to survive the cold before attempting to go on with the mission).

121207.name: Discover the Aliens
121207.description:
Game play:
Each player takes a playing board, feature detector, and marker, then draws a feature card. Only aliens showing this feature live on the player's planet. Each player tries to find out the feature card that the other player drew.

On their turn, a player draws a face-down alien card and asks the other player if that alien lives on that player's planet. If the player says yes, the alien is placed on the first player's planet, if not, it is placed on the outer space area. The first player then crosses off any features that they can rule out on their feature detector, and it is the next player's turn.

Instead of their turn, a player can also guess the other player's secret feature. If they are right, they get a planet card and the round ends; if they are wrong, they lose a turn. At the end of a round, players wipe clean their feature detectors, shuffle the alien and feature cards, draw new feature cards and start another round.

The winner is the player who wins their fifth planet card.

In the advanced rules, two feature cards are drawn, and only aliens showing both features live on that planet, and the game finishes after one round.

121208.name: Top Level
121208.description:
User Summary

Top Level is a very fast arcade driving game. The player must drive a car around obstacles on a vertically scrolling road.

The game has only two levels, but side B of the floppy has a sprite and level editor for the players to create their own roads.

121209.name: Le Manoir Du Comte Frozarda
videogameversion: French Amstrad CPC Floppy Disk edition
121209.description:
User Summary

A text adventure heavily inspired by Bram Stoker's Dracula. The protagonist, a young Transylvanian peasant, hasn't been paying much attention to the rumors about young girls disappearing near Count Frozarda, until his fiancée disappears too. He sets out to find her and investigate the mystery.

121210.name: Scalextric
videogameversion: English/European Amstrad CPC Floppy Disk edition
121210.description:
User Summary

Scalextric is a computer simulation of electric race cars toys (toys where you build a track out of plastic parts on which toy cars with a small electric motor can move). The game includes two modes, racing, against either a live opponent or the computer on one of the ten prebuilt tracks, and construction kit, where players can design tracks and test them.

The game was developed under a licence from Scalextric, a company manufacturing such toys.

121211.name: Cookie Monster Munch
121211.description:
Cookie Monster Munch is a video game developed by Atari and Children's Computer Workshop for the Atari 2600 and released in 1983.[1] The game was programmed by Gary Stark.
The objective of Cookie Monster Munch is to guide Sesame Street's Cookie Monster through a simple maze, collecting cookies and placing them in a cookie jar at the bottom of the screen.
Cookie Monster Munch used an Atari Kid's Controller (sold separately), although the regular keyboard controller would also work.

Source: Wikipedia, "Cookie Monster Munch", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

121212.name: Tooth Protectors
121212.description:
Released in 1983, Tooth Protectors is one of the earliest "advergames" or "promogames" – games with overt tie-ins to retail products – and one of several released that year for the Atari 2600 platform (others included M Network's Kool-Aid Man and Purina's Chase the Chuck Wagon.) Commissioned by Johnson & Johnson and developed by DSD/Camelot, it was the only game released for the Atari 2600 by either company.

The gameplay is similar to that of Activision's Kaboom!, in which the player must prevent objects dropping from the top of the screen from reaching the bottom by positioning their character directly under the falling objects. In Tooth Protectors, the objects are small "snack" squares dropped by the "Snack Attacker", a menacing-looking face that moves horizontally along the top of the screen. The player's character is a small smiling face carrying a strand of dental floss above its head. The player must prevent the snack squares from reaching the row of white teeth along the bottom of the screen; repeated hits by the snacks cause the teeth to blink and disappear from tooth decay. Occasionally the Snack Attacker will dive from the top of the screen in an attempt to grab the player; the player loses a turn if the Snack Attacker succeeds. If teeth begin to decay, the player can press the joystick's fire button to call in the "Tooth Protectors": an orange toothbrush, green box of dental floss and purple dental rinse bottle move across the teeth, brushing, flossing and rinsing them.

Source: Wikipedia, "Tooth Protectors", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

121213.name: I Want My Mommy
121213.description:
I Want My Mommy is a rare video game for the Atari 2600; released exclusively to North America. The game is considered to be a Donkey Kong-type platformer where teleportation beams connect upward on the playing field. Monsters can be faked out by partially going up a teleporter then coming back down again.

Source: Wikipedia, "I Want My Mommy", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

121214.name: Rally Point Volume 6: Advanced Squad Leader Starter Kit Special Study II
121214.description:
Rally Point Volume 6: Starter Kit Special Study II is an ASL/ASL Starter Kit Compatible scenario pack that uses the components of Starter Kits 1-3, Starter Kit Expansion Pack #1 and Starter Kit Bounus Pack #1. Each scenario is fully compatible with full ASL rules and ASL Starter Kit Rules. These 10 scenarios were playtested with consideration for both rules sets and are presented in the Schwerpunkt easy-to-read format on high-quality cardstock.

RPT51 Arrivederci Nembo: Delianuona, Italy, 7 September 1943: Elements of the Italian Nembo Parachute Division found Lieutenant Colonel Bogert’s lead platoons of the West Novas resting along the road.
